coverage: Comprehensive Daniel: prophet & companions; angels (Gabriel, Michael), heavenly court (Ancient of Days, Son of Man), watchers; Babylon→Persia kings; court guilds; narrative icons (food test, furnace, tree, writing, lions); apocalyptic bestiary (Dan 7 beasts, horns; Dan 8 ram/goat), timelines (70 weeks, 2,300 evenings-mornings, 1,290/1,335), abomination; kings of North/South; prayer/fasting, wisdom, saints’ kingdom; bilingual architecture & chiastic design; places (Babylon, Dura, Susa/Ulai, Tigris); laws/edicts & royal doxologies; reception history (Greek additions).
id_scheme: Cross-book stable by (type+primary-slug) with alias support; deterministic for new entries; reuses shared entities when slugs match.

entries.name: Ezekiel son of Buzi
entries.blurb: Priest‑prophet among the exiles by the Chebar canal. Commissioned by the Glory to speak to a hard‑foreheaded people; his body and biography become the message.

entries.name: Buzi (father of Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Priestly father whose name signals Ezekiel’s temple literacy and passion for holiness.

entries.name: Ezekiel’s wife (‘the delight of your eyes’)
entries.blurb: Her sudden death becomes a sign: as the temple—the people’s delight—is taken away, mourning is muted; grief turns theological.

entries.name: Elders of Israel in exile (inquirers)
entries.blurb: Leaders who come seeking a word yet are confronted with their idolatry; inquiry without obedience is judged.

entries.name: Exilic community by the Chebar canal
entries.blurb: Audience of Ezekiel’s sign‑acts; neighbors who talk about the prophet as a performer but must heed his words to live.

entries.name: The sighing man (marked remnant)
entries.blurb: Those who grieve abominations receive a protective mark—judgment discriminates by contrition.

entries.name: False prophets of Israel
entries.blurb: Whitewash flimsy walls; promise peace where there is none—prophecy as PR is dismantled by storm.

entries.name: Prophetesses with bands and veils
entries.blurb: Women who ensnare souls with magical paraphernalia; God tears off the charms to free the hunted life.

entries.name: Jehoiachin (Jeconiah) in exile
entries.blurb: Exiled Davidic king whose reign marks Ezekiel’s dates—a living reminder that the monarchy is under judgment yet preserved.

entries.name: Zedekiah (‘prince in Jerusalem’)
entries.blurb: Covenant‑breaker who seeks Egypt; Ezekiel predicts his capture and blindness—oath‑breaking as sacrilege.

entries.name: Nebuchadnezzar II of Babylon (‘king of kings’)
entries.blurb: Instrument of God’s justice against Tyre and Egypt; even empire’s wages are reckoned by the LORD.

entries.name: Pharaoh (Hophra/Apries horizon)
entries.blurb: Self‑exalting ruler pictured as a Nile monster; his arm is broken, his pride felled—Egypt’s mythic power is leashed.

entries.name: Prince of Tyre
entries.blurb: Human ruler deified by commerce and wisdom; reminded he is but a man before the God he mimics.

entries.name: King of Tyre (lament figure)
entries.blurb: Lament paints primeval splendor and downfall; royal hubris reads like an Adamic recapitulation in a trading empire’s key.

entries.name: Prince of Egypt
entries.blurb: Target of judgment oracles; cities crumble and idols cease—political power is theological.

entries.name: King of Sidon
entries.blurb: Brief oracle: judgment purges scorn; Israel’s neighbors become sanctifying instruments not thorns.

entries.name: Ammon (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Glee at Israel’s demise is rebuked; desolation and Moabite possession follow—schadenfreude is a policy God overturns.

entries.name: Moab (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: ‘Judah is like all nations’—Moab’s leveling taunt elicits a surgical judgment that opens Israel to vindication.

entries.name: Edom (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Perpetual enmity targeted; Mount Seir becomes a desolation—violence against Israel ricochets against Edom.

entries.name: Philistia (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Old hostilities meet new retribution; vengeance with wrath teaches YHWH’s identity among the nations.

entries.name: Tyre (city and network)
entries.blurb: Maritime hub whose trade web (ch. 27) maps the world’s desires; when the hub falls, the economy mourns like a funeral at sea.

entries.name: Sidon (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Nearby power pruned of pride—Israel’s neighborhood will be cleansed of contempt.

entries.name: Egypt (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: River kingdom pictured as a crocodile; boasts of the Nile are broken; she descends among the slain in the netherworld laments.

entries.name: Assyria as a towering cedar
entries.blurb: Once lofty above the nations, felled by the ruthless of the nations—parable for Egypt and all proud trees.

entries.name: House of Israel (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Corporate covenant identity addressed in judgment and hope; the goal is a heart that knows the LORD.

entries.name: House of Judah (Ezekiel)
entries.blurb: Southern kingdom as distinct addressee; responsibility is personal (ch. 18) yet never isolated from communal calling.

entries.name: Remnant spared for witness
entries.blurb: Survivors confess idols were vain; their testimony justifies God and seeds renewal.

entries.name: Shepherds of Israel (bad leaders)
entries.blurb: Feed themselves, not the flock; God Himself will shepherd—and set over them David my servant.

entries.name: Flock of the LORD (rescued)
entries.blurb: YHWH seeks the strayed, heals the injured, and judges fat and lean sheep—justice as pastoral care.

entries.name: Sons of Zadok (faithful priests)
entries.blurb: Priestly line kept from idolatry; entrusted with altar service in the future temple—holiness institutionalized.

entries.name: Levites who went astray
entries.blurb: Still serve, but at a distance; their unfaithfulness reorders cultic proximity—mercy with memory.

entries.name: Princes of the land (allotments)
entries.blurb: A prince bounded by just weights and land rights—royal power tamed by holiness and equity.

entries.name: Merchants and mariners of Tyre
entries.blurb: From Tarshish to Javan, a chorus of traders mourns the sinking of a globalized economy—commerce is not neutral in prophetic ethics.

entries.name: Women weeping for Tammuz
entries.blurb: Cult of dying‑rising god intrudes the temple; grief rituals co‑opted for idolatry.

entries.name: Seventy elders with censers
entries.blurb: Incense before carved images in the temple’s dark rooms—leadership hypocrisy unmasked.

entries.name: Twenty‑five men worshiping the sun
entries.blurb: Backs to the temple, faces east—cosmic treason in the inner court; creation worship replaces Creator.

entries.name: Glory of the LORD (kavod) — appearing in Babylon
entries.blurb: Storm‑throne chariot with living creatures and wheels within wheels; the God of Israel is mobile, sovereign in exile.

entries.name: Glory departs the temple
entries.blurb: From threshold to east gate to the mount—presence withdraws in stages; judgment explained as relational rupture.

entries.name: Glory returns to the new temple
entries.blurb: The earth‑filling radiance enters by the east gate; the sanctuary becomes the axis of renewed creation.

entries.name: Living creatures / Cherubim
entries.blurb: Four‑faced beings bearing the throne; later named ‘cherubim’—hybrid guardians of holiness and mobility.

entries.name: Wheels within wheels, full of eyes
entries.blurb: Omnidirectional movement and perception—vision of providence that sees and acts everywhere.

entries.name: Man with a measuring reed and line
entries.blurb: Bronze‑like being who guides Ezekiel through the temple tour—order, proportion, and holiness measured out.

entries.name: Man clothed in linen with writing kit
entries.blurb: Marks the mourners; executes judgment protocol—liturgy and justice coordinated by heaven.

entries.name: Hand of the LORD / Spirit transportations
entries.blurb: Prophetic ecstasy moves Ezekiel across spaces and scenes; revelation is embodied relocation.

entries.name: River of life from the temple
entries.blurb: Trickles to a torrent healing the Dead Sea; trees bear fruit monthly—creation renewed from the holy presence.

entries.name: Eating the scroll (sweet/bitter calling)
entries.blurb: The prophet internalizes the message; he speaks digestion—word becomes flesh in his ministry.

entries.name: Mute until news arrives
entries.blurb: Silence as sign until Jerusalem falls; speech restored for restoration oracles—timing is theology.

entries.name: Brick and siege model
entries.blurb: A miniature Jerusalem under siege—prophetic street theater that preaches strategy and doom.

entries.name: Lying on left and right sides
entries.blurb: 390 days for Israel, 40 for Judah—bearing iniquity dramatized in the prophet’s body.

entries.name: Defiled rations baked over dung
entries.blurb: Scarcity and uncleanness of exile previewed; concession to cow dung signals mitigated mercy.

entries.name: Shaving hair and dividing thirds
entries.blurb: A third burned, a third struck, a third scattered—few hairs tucked in as remnant; judgment in proportions.

entries.name: Packing baggage for exile
entries.blurb: Dig through the wall, go out at dusk—Zedekiah’s fate encoded in a prophet’s pantomime.

entries.name: Sword sharpened and polished
entries.blurb: A flashing sword dances in prophetic hands—judgment is imminent and indiscriminate among the wicked.

entries.name: Sighing and smiting the thigh
entries.blurb: Embodied groans communicate terror ahead—prophet feels before he speaks.

entries.name: Cooking pot / rusty cauldron
entries.blurb: Jerusalem as a pot whose rust will not go out—blood guilt baked in; only fire answers.

entries.name: Prophet’s wife taken; no mourning
entries.blurb: Personal bereavement as public oracle; silence becomes sermon for a stunned community.

entries.name: Two sticks joined (Judah & Joseph)
entries.blurb: Reunification enacted; one king over one people under an everlasting covenant and sanctuary presence.

entries.name: Valley of dry bones
entries.blurb: Spirit breathes on slain bones; graves open—resurrection imagery pledges national restoration and more.

entries.name: Watchman charge (I & II)
entries.blurb: Accountability for warning; bloodguilt lifted by faithful speech—pastoral vigilance codified.

entries.name: Allegory of the unfaithful bride (Jerusalem)
entries.blurb: From abandoned infant to adorned queen to adulterous city—grace abused becomes a courtroom drama.

entries.name: Parable of the eagles and the vine
entries.blurb: Babylon and Egypt as great eagles; Judah’s treachery is horticultural folly—rooted politics gone wrong.

entries.name: Promise of the tender twig / cedar on high
entries.blurb: God plants a sprig that becomes shelter for birds—kingdom hope after failed statecraft.

entries.name: Lament for the princes of Israel (lions’ whelps)
entries.blurb: Royal cubs learn to tear prey and are caged; a vine is uprooted—Davidic pathos under judgment.

entries.name: Allegory of two sisters: Oholah & Oholibah
entries.blurb: Samaria and Jerusalem personified as promiscuous sisters; shocking satire of political idolatry.

entries.name: Rusty cauldron song
entries.blurb: A grim cooking song indicting Jerusalem’s entrenched bloodguilt—kitchen liturgy of justice.

entries.name: Dirge for Tyre, the trading ship
entries.blurb: Every mast and sail named; when the ship sinks, the world’s markets wail—commerce can be an idol with a funeral.

entries.name: Laments over Pharaoh and Egypt
entries.blurb: Monster hauled up with hooks; descent among the uncircumcised—mythic pride meets Sheol’s realism.

entries.name: Abominations at the temple (four scenes)
entries.blurb: From the idol at the north gate to elders in chambers, women for Tammuz, and sun‑worshipers—cumulative desecration triggers departure of glory.

entries.name: Executioners and the man in linen
entries.blurb: Six with weapons plus one scribe—judgment begins at the sanctuary; holiness is not safe for hypocrisy.

entries.name: Glory leaves threshold and east gate
entries.blurb: Vacating the holy house step by step—the slow grief of divine departure.

entries.name: Glory stands on the mountain east of the city
entries.blurb: Presence pauses eastward as if waiting for repentance—mercy lingers even in judgment.

entries.name: Return of glory by the east gate
entries.blurb: Sanctuary re‑inhabited; holiness returns as gift, not presumption—architecture serves presence.

entries.name: East gate shut for the Prince
entries.blurb: Reserved access signifies reverence; the Prince’s worship exemplifies ordered leadership.

entries.name: Altar of burnt offering (dimensions & consecration)
entries.blurb: Four horns, steps to the east; a week‑long ordination liturgy reinstates sacrificial fellowship.

entries.name: Zadokite priests: clothing, duties, holiness
entries.blurb: Instructions on garments, hair, marriages, teaching, and judgment—holiness woven into everyday service.

entries.name: Levites’ demotion and service
entries.blurb: They bear iniquity of past idolatry; serve at gates and slaughter but stay back from the altar—mercy disciplines memory.

entries.name: Chambers for singers and priests
entries.blurb: Music and ministry have designated spaces—worship is architected, not improvised.

entries.name: Boiling places and kitchens
entries.blurb: Sacred food preparation zones prevent holy from mingling with common—design as catechesis.

entries.name: Prince’s offerings and Sabbaths
entries.blurb: The Prince funds and models festival worship—politics underwrites piety without usurping priestly roles.

entries.name: Just weights, ephah, and shekel
entries.blurb: Holiness entails economic honesty; corrupted scales profane the land.

entries.name: Holy district and sacred allotment
entries.blurb: A central strip for sanctuary, priests, Levites, and the city—land use encodes theological priorities.

entries.name: Tribal allotments (restored land)
entries.blurb: Bands from north to south equalize access; ancient names become eschatological geography.

entries.name: City gates named for tribes
entries.blurb: Twelve gates inscribe identity into architecture—belonging is built into coming and going.

entries.name: City name: ‘The LORD is there’ (YHWH Shammah)
entries.blurb: Final word of the book: presence defines the polis—God’s nearness is the city’s security.

entries.name: ‘Son of Man’ (ben ’adam) address
entries.blurb: God’s repeated address to Ezekiel underscores creatureliness and vocation—humility fitted for high vision.

entries.name: ‘They shall know that I am the LORD’ refrain
entries.blurb: Recognition formula punctuates judgments and restorations; theology aims at doxology in history.

entries.name: Individual responsibility and the soul that sins shall die
entries.blurb: Proverbs about sour grapes are retired; repentance is real time, not genealogy—God delights to save.

entries.name: Corporate memory and stubbornness
entries.blurb: A long courtroom rehearsal of rebellion in Egypt, wilderness, and land—grace keeps choosing for His name’s sake.

entries.name: New heart and new spirit
entries.blurb: Stone to flesh; Spirit within—obedience becomes gift before it is task.

entries.name: Sprinkled clean water and indwelling Spirit
entries.blurb: Purification and presence repair covenant—holiness becomes habitat.

entries.name: David my servant: shepherd‑king
entries.blurb: A Davidic ruler under God shepherds a united people—royalty recast as pastoral care.

entries.name: Covenant of peace / everlasting covenant
entries.blurb: Shalom covenant yields safety, fruitfulness, sanctuary presence—Edenic echoes in exile.

entries.name: Abominations list and anatomy of idolatry
entries.blurb: From heart idols to public rites—prophetic diagnosis links liturgy to life.

entries.name: Proverb: ‘The days are prolonged’ refuted
entries.blurb: Delay does not cancel judgment; the word hastens to perform—prophetic timing is moral, not mechanical.

entries.name: Proverb: ‘The fathers ate sour grapes’ refuted
entries.blurb: Inherited blame gives way to personal responsibility—each soul stands before God.

entries.name: Defilement of land and bloodguilt
entries.blurb: Violence pollutes; only purgative judgment and renewed worship cleanse a place.

entries.name: Justice in commerce and governance
entries.blurb: Oppression, bribery, and unequal measures profane God’s name—holiness is measured in markets too.

entries.name: Gog of the land of Magog
entries.blurb: Archetypal invader from the far north; a cipher for final hostility gathered against God’s people.

entries.name: Magog, Meshech, and Tubal
entries.blurb: Peoples marshaled under Gog; geopolitics become theater for divine reputation.

entries.name: Hooks in the jaws; God’s sovereignty in war
entries.blurb: Aggression is leashed and led—God drags the dragon to its own defeat.

entries.name: Earthquake, hail, fire, and brimstone
entries.blurb: Cosmic judgments unmake the invaders; creation fights for its Maker.

entries.name: Great feast of birds and beasts
entries.blurb: Sacrificial banquet where enemies become the offering—reversal of power through holy irony.

entries.name: Burying of Gog: Valley of Hamon‑gog
entries.blurb: Seven months to cleanse the land; markers for bones—holiness includes public sanitation after war.

entries.name: House of Israel knows the LORD from that day forward
entries.blurb: Judgment and mercy culminate in recognition and Spirit outpouring—exile read as pedagogy of grace.

entries.name: Date formula: fifth year, fourth month, fifth day
entries.blurb: Precision timestamps Ezekiel’s vision; sacred history keeps a calendar.

entries.name: Mute sign resumes: twelfth year, tenth month, fifth day
entries.blurb: News of the city’s fall arrives; a long silence breaks—new phase of ministry begins.

entries.name: Twenty‑fifth year, beginning of temple vision
entries.blurb: ‘Head of the year’ marks the grand tour of the future temple—hope is architected.

entries.name: Vision transports (‘in the visions of God’)
entries.blurb: Spatial shifts locate prophecy between earth and heaven—mystical geography for pastoral ends.

entries.name: Rhetorical refrain: ‘set your face toward…’
entries.blurb: Command formula that turns the prophet like a compass—speech as directional warfare.

entries.name: Proverb and riddle (ḥidah) technique
entries.blurb: Encrypted speech invites engagement, then clarification—education by mystery.

entries.name: Merkabah tradition (chariot mysticism) seedbed
entries.blurb: Later Jewish mystical readings find ascent patterns here; Ezekiel remains anchored in covenant ethics, not escape.

entries.name: Influence on Revelation (throne, river, city)
entries.blurb: John riffs on Ezekiel’s imagery—Christian reception reads temple as eschatological presence fulfilled.

entries.name: Chebar canal (Kebar)
entries.blurb: Exilic waterway in Babylonia—becomes a sanctuary of visions; God localizes glory among the displaced.

entries.name: Tel‑Abib (Tel‑aviv) by the Chebar
entries.blurb: Settlement where Ezekiel sits overwhelmed seven days; pastoral incubation before speech.

entries.name: Jerusalem (Ezekiel’s vision focus)
entries.blurb: City under siege, defiled, and deserted by glory—yet target of future cleansing and re‑inhabitation.

entries.name: North gate of the altar
entries.blurb: Site of the provocative idol—threshold of desecration that triggers the tour of abominations.

entries.name: Inner court of the LORD’s house
entries.blurb: Stage of sun worship and glory’s cloud—profanation and presence collide.

entries.name: East gate of the house of the LORD
entries.blurb: Processional portal for departure and return of glory; now dignified by the Prince’s rites.

entries.name: Valley full of bones
entries.blurb: Locale of the resurrection vision—God’s clinic for pastoral imagination.

entries.name: Valley of Hamon‑gog
entries.blurb: Burying ground east of the sea—memory of judgment curated for generations.
